newsitem.title: USA: Venture-backed IPOs slow down in '97 first quarter.
newsitem.headline: Venture-backed IPOs slow down in '97 first quarter.

text.p: The number of venture-backed initial public offerings in the first quarter of 1997 was well below last year's first quarter, according to data released by research and consulting firm Venture Economics Information Services, a division of Securities Data Company Inc.

Thirty two companies that had venture capital firms listed as principal shareholders went public during the first three months of 1997, raising $960 million, compared with 61 companies raising $2.33 billion in the first quarter of 1996.

The first quarter of 1997 did, however, boast the largest post-offering valuation of a venture-backed IPO ever. Ciena Corp, which went public in February, was valued at $2.14 billion upon completion of its public offering, according to Venture Economics.

The data also showed that the average offering size decreased to $30 million this year from $38.2 million in last year's first quarter. Venture-backed IPOs as a percentage of overall IPOs slipped to 23 percent, compared with 36 percent for the first quarter of 1996 and 31 percent for the year.

In the face of current market volatility and the battering suffered by hi-tech stocks, venture capitalists' "appetites have slackened a bit," Jesse Reyes, Director of Venture Economics Information Services, told Reuters.
Roughly two-thirds of all venture-backed IPOs tend to be in the hi-tech arena, said Reyes. This fraction was even higher in 1995 and 1996.

Reyes also said that the IPO boom in the last couple of years was characterized by companies, particularly hi-tech ones, rushing to market "much sooner than they might have ordinarily done in a less robust market".
That was no longer the case. The market had reached a saturation point and investors, as well as financial backers, were being far more selective, analysts have said.

"Venture capitalists are still very interested in technology companies but I think they're looking for ...more experience based on the management team and a much more solid foundation for growth," said Robert Fish, partner in charge of Coopers & Lybrand's venture capital and hi-tech practice in New York.

He said venture capital firms were taking a longer-term view on companies they backed, committing to a more traditional three to five year time horizon, as opposed to hurrying the deal to the marketplace and then beating a hasty retreat after cashing in the gains.
